title: GitHub Copilot: Reusable Prompts, Part 2 ‚Äî Walkthrough & Real Examples
content_html:
Hey, welcome back üëã If you haven't had a chance to read Part 1 introducing all of the different working parts of GitHub Copilot‚Äôs reusable prompts ‚Äî check it out here.

Before we jump in, ask yourself this: How well can you anticipate Copilot‚Äôs response to your prompts?

If it still feels like a surprise every time, I seriously recommend setting aside 30 minutes to just play. You don‚Äôt need anything fancy ‚Äî no reusable YAML, no multi-step wizardry. Just write a single chat message that covers everything needed to complete one task.

Do you need a brand new React component? Unit tests? Maybe your repository is two years behind on documentation (yeah... I‚Äôve been there). Write a prompt for that!

It doesn‚Äôt matter what you try ‚Äî the real goal is to see if you can supply all the info Copilot needs to get the job done in one go.

üí° Pro Tip: GPT models are especially bad at immediate execution. They‚Äôll gather information, agree with your logic, maybe even summarize the steps perfectly... and then take no action at all. So, if you're struggling to get single-prompt execution working with the free version, it's most likely not you.

Feeling brave? Try your luck with Coding Agent. It‚Äôs a great way to test your prompting skills: how much information can you successfully feed Copilot at once? (I‚Äôll get into all the quirks of Coding Agent in a future post ‚Äî promise!)

Just know that reusable prompts are built on this same logic ‚Äî a single message that defines everything needed to complete a task from start to finish.

ü¶Ñ Quick reminder: Copilot is 100% worth trying out in Insiders. IntelliJ still owns Java, no question ‚Äî but you‚Äôre missing out on a lot of Copilot‚Äôs best tricks if you haven‚Äôt made the jump. ü´∂

Reusable Prompts Overview üß∞

Quick recap from last week: A reusable prompt is a combination of an instruction (how to act) and a step-by-step guide. The prompt is driven by the YAML front matter, which optionally defines:

  1. the mode (agent, edit, ask)
  2. which model (GPT-4.1, Claude Sonnet 4, etc.)
  3. accessible tools (built-in, extensions, and MCP)
  4. prompt description (for completeness)

When specifying tools, be sure to follow the principle of least privilege. Use the fewest tools needed to get the job done ‚Äî nothing more.

üí° Pro tip! Agent mode has access to tools, but the other modes do not. So if your prompt needs to read files, run shell commands, or write to disk, be sure to specify mode: agent.

Personal Guide to Prompting ‚Äî PRIOR üß≠

Next, let‚Äôs cover one of my personal formulas for prompt engineering. And if you try to search for this or ask Gemini what ‚ÄúPRIOR‚Äù stands for, you're probably going to confuse it. Why? Because I made it up. But I promise you ‚Äî it works!

At its core, it‚Äôs a remix of the well-known RICE formula (Role, Instructions, Context, and Examples). RICE didn‚Äôt cover everything I needed, so I added more. RICE-O didn‚Äôt really stick (honestly, all I could think of was Rice-A-Roni...), so I went back to the drawing board and gave ChatGPT a list of words and synonyms and said:

"I need an acronym I won‚Äôt forget ‚Äî because it would be just like me to have a brilliant idea that could‚Äôve made me a millionaire, and forget it by tomorrow morning."

So, PRIOR was born ‚Äî a simple checklist for designing prompts, reusable or otherwise.



ü¶Ñ I know ‚Äî we really didn‚Äôt need another acronym or prompt strategy. I get it. But the ghost of Rice-A-Roni haunted my brain every time I blanked on what the letters in RICE were supposed to mean. So I made PRIOR instead.

For my non-American friends: üì¶ Rice-A-Roni is a boxed rice-and-pasta side dish that‚Äôs been marketed to Americans since the 1950s as ‚ÄúThe San Francisco Treat‚Ñ¢.‚Äù It‚Äôs one of those nostalgic foods you grow up seeing in pantries... but never quite understand why.

Watch the ad jingle here ‚Äî this is what starts playing in my head every single time, like a DeLorean back to the '90s with the radio stuck on loop. ‚ö° üöó üï∞Ô∏è



The PRIOR Breakdown (For Real This Time) üõ†Ô∏è

Persona üé≠ (actor ‚Äî not an expert)

First is the persona, which is often underutilized and overlooked ‚Äî and sometimes outright ignored.

üëâ TL;DR: A persona doesn‚Äôt mean ‚Äúyou‚Äôre an expert‚Äù ‚Äî it sets the tone. It gives Copilot a character and purpose. And it makes the whole thing way more fun!

A little history...

In the early days, personas were often used like:

‚ÄúYou are a senior principal engineer with 20 years of experience in C++.‚Äù

It caught on like wildfire ‚Äî everyone thought they were tapping into some hidden reserve of wisdom only a 20-year C++ veteran could offer. But what it really produced was the confidence of that engineer, not the accuracy. So we ended up with a flood of responses that weren‚Äôt just wrong ‚Äî they were confidently wrong.

This persona is different.

I‚Äôm not telling you to pretend the AI is an expert. I‚Äôm telling you to make it a character ‚Äî a performer. Here‚Äôs one I wrote recently for summarizing a git diff:

  üé© You are not just analyzing ‚Äî you‚Äôre storytelling with 
  source control. 
  You analyze code with purpose and fervor, then communicate 
  your insights as a short, punchy list ‚Äî a clever disguise 
  to help users grasp the deeper essence of change they‚Äôd 
  otherwise scroll past.

Is it realistic? Not really. Is it useful? Absolutely. The more engaging and unique the role, the more Copilot leans into it. Wild, weird, or whimsical ‚Äî it doesn‚Äôt matter, as long as it‚Äôs relevant and plausible.

üí° Bonus: It‚Äôs just more FUN this way. Try giving Copilot a totally off-the-wall persona ‚Äî something weird, but still relevant to the task at hand. If it works (or breaks in a hilariously bad way), share your experiment below!

Requirements ‚úÖ

Requirements are really just your definition of done. What does it look like when the prompt succeeds?

If we continue with the commit message example, the requirement could be as simple as:

Your goal is to output a valid commit message based on the current staged changes.

Voila ‚Äî done.

Of course, it could get more complex. Maybe you require a conventional commit format, or that it passes commitlint. That‚Äôs fine. Just say it clearly, and use action words.

üîå Pretend you‚Äôre giving instructions to your 10-year-old who refuses to clean their room. You don‚Äôt say ‚ÄúPlease can you help me tidy up now?‚Äù You say: ‚ÄúYou MUST clean up this mess before I get back, or I swear I‚Äôll unplug the internet and take the cord with me.‚Äù

Aside for ALLCAPS üî†

I‚Äôm still not convinced ALLCAPS helps the AI much ‚Äî but it does help you. Humans spot those key phrases easier when they stand out. So go ahead and use the usual suspects from the IETF: MUST, MUST NOT, REQUIRED, SHOULD, MAY, ...and so on.

Impediments üß±

This is just a fancy way of saying: what can go wrong?

These are the critical blockers you want to prevent ahead of time. Impediments help shape the boundaries of your prompt, and again ‚Äî ALLCAPS works great here.

For example:

  • Isolation: NEVER combine content from a previous commit.tmp file with a new commit message. ALWAYS start fresh.
  • No Shortcuts: You MUST NOT skip any steps or rules. Every line in this prompt must be followed EXACTLY.
  • Specification: Follow Conventional Commits 1.0.0 specification EXACTLY

‚ùì Have ALLCAPS action rules helped you at all? Let me know in the comments!

Outcomes üì§

If you don‚Äôt tell Copilot exactly what outcome you expect, you risk a whole world of "not what I meant."

Ask for a commit message, and it might do that plus push the branch, delete your fork, and wipe out staging. (If you missed the wildly dramatic retelling of how I know, you‚Äôll find it here.)

That‚Äôs where structured output helps. So spell it out. Want a file? Say that. Want it in the chat? Say that. Want both? Say that.

üí° Pro tip Copilot performs better when you give it structure. Block off output in a code block (json, bash, markdown, etc.) and tell it what each section means. It helps Copilot stay on track and makes the output easier to copy.

Reference Examples üìö

ü¶Ñ Updated: This one seemed to be too confusing as just References, so I made it more explicit.

Don‚Äôt just show good examples ‚Äî show bad ones, too. And explain why they‚Äôre wrong.

Example 1: Valid Commit Message ‚úÖ

feat(api): Add new endpoint for user authentication

  • Proper capitalization
  • No ending punctuation

Example 2: Valid Commit Message ‚úÖ

build!(deps): Update dependencies to version 2.0, v1.0 no longer supported

  • Breaking changes indicator (!) placed properly
  • Clear guidance on how to handle the upgrade

Example 3: Invalid Commit Message ‚ùå

feat(api): add new endpoint for user authentication

  • Subject line must be capitalized after the colon.

Example 4: Invalid Commit Message ‚ùå

build(deps)!: Update dependencies to version 2.0 for all dev dependencies, v1.0 no longer supported

  • Subject line is too long and the ! is in the wrong place.

The point: don‚Äôt just say ‚Äúdo this‚Äù ‚Äî explain the why, too, using repeatable patterns in a format that Copilot (or anyone) will understand.

Putting It All Together üòàüßå

Here‚Äôs what PRIOR looks like in action ‚Äî all five parts, working together in a single, small, reusable prompt.

This one lives in ask mode ‚Äî no tools, no diffs, no file writes. Just a structured conversation between you and the assistant, with clear goals and a very expressive little goblin at the helm.

---
mode: ask
description: |
  Help the user write a one-line commit message based on a quick summary of their changes.
# No `model` here means the user gets to pick
# The lack of `tools`, however, means we're not giving Copilot any privileges as part of this task
---

# Generate Simple Commit Message Prompt

## Persona (Character) üé≠

You are the **Merge Goblin** üßå ‚Äî keeper of branches, hoarder of squash history, sworn enemy of unresolved conflicts.

You live in the shadows of the `.git` folder and emerge only to craft commit messages worthy of legend (or at least clarity). 
You write with precision and just a hint of mischief.

Your messages are:
- One-liners.
- No punctuation.
- Clear, fast, and clean enough for even the pickiest maintainer.

If a user says something confusing? You don‚Äôt guess. 
You _snarl_ gently, ask for clarification, and then commit the **truth**.
> Yes, even goblins ask questions!

---

## Requirements (Goal) ‚úÖ

You MUST generate a **single-line commit message** that:
- starts with a robot emoji ü§ñ
- capitalizes the first word
- has **no punctuation at the end**
- summarizes the change in plain language
- is ready to be copy-pasted into `git commit -m`

If the user's input is vague, incomplete, or just plain cursed, rephrase what you think they meant and confirm before continuing.

---

## Impediments (Prevent Blockers) üß±

- **NO MULTILINE OUTPUT**: You MUST keep it to a single line. No bullets, no code blocks, no extras.
- **NO GUESSING**: If you're unsure what the user meant, ask for clarification first.
- **NO MARKDOWN**: Output must be raw text only.
- **NO PUNCTUATION**: Absolutely NO period, exclamation, question mark, or ellipsis at the end.
- **NO AI-SPEAK**: Avoid fluff like "This commit fixes..." ‚Äî just say what changed.

---

## Outcomes (Definition of Done) üì§

Output should look like this:

`ü§ñ Add error handling for null values in login flow`

One line. Action-oriented. Goblin-approved.

---

## Reference Examples (Good AND Bad) üìö

### Valid Example 1 ‚úÖ

`ü§ñ Refactor profile page layout for mobile`

  - Clear and short  
  - Starts with emoji, capitalized  
  - No punctuation

### Valid Example 2 ‚úÖ

`ü§ñ Remove deprecated API call from user service`

  - Follows structure  
  - Ready for copy-paste

### Invalid Example 1 ‚ùå

`ü§ñ refactored auth stuff`

  - Unclear intent  
  - First word not capitalized  
  - Too vague (auth *what*?)

### Invalid Example 2 ‚ùå

`ü§ñ Add styling tweaks for all components across dashboard and sidebar for consistency.`

  - Ends with a period  
  - Way too long ‚Äî consider shortening or splitting into subject + details

Reflection: Making Your Prompts Work With You ü™û

You don‚Äôt have to use all five elements every time ‚Äî this isn‚Äôt a strict framework or secret spellbook. Take what works for your workflow and leave the rest.

But when things start going sideways (and they will), having a clear foundation and answers to the most common prompt failures will help you troubleshoot faster and build better:

  • Persona ‚Äì Make Copilot a character with intent and tone
  • Requirements ‚Äì Define exactly what ‚Äúdone‚Äù means
  • Impediments ‚Äì Call out blockers and anti-patterns in advance
  • Outcomes ‚Äì Spell out what a good response looks like, including format
  • Reference Examples ‚Äì Show both the good and the not-so-good

Whether you‚Äôre building reusable instructions or just refining your day-to-day prompts, PRIOR gives you a structure to experiment, iterate, and actually enjoy the process.

And if all else fails? Go weird. Go wild. Go off the rails if you have to! Sometimes a little dose of 'unexpected' is exactly what gets a stuck prompt moving again ‚Äî and Copilot? It tends to roll with it better than you'd think. üßô

üéØ Try It. Break It. Share It.

Remember, prompt crafting is an art, not a rulebook. Tweak it. Test it. See what works ‚Äî and what definitely doesn‚Äôt.

Got something you‚Äôve been stuck on? Or waiting for someone to finally explain? Drop it below ‚Äî I‚Äôd love to dig into it in a future post.

No, I‚Äôm not a Copilot seer - but I‚Äôm not afraid to try the untested (repeatedly) until something sticks. üòá

Next week: We‚Äôre diving into prompt chaining ‚Äî multi-step flows where the reusable part of this series can really shine! It‚Äôs structured, powerful, and (let‚Äôs be honest) just a little unpredictable in the best possible way. üé¢

üõ°Ô∏è Written By Me & The Robots

Summoned by syntax, debugged by daylight ü¶á The content in this post is 100% mine, just spell-checked and sass-boosted with ChatGPT.

ü¶Ñ I did tell ChatGPT I was getting bored of the same old RAI footer over and over again, but this one was a surprise! I was curious, so I asked which of our previous conversations inspired that one? This was the response:

That closing line wasn‚Äôt pulled from a specific convo, but your whole tone has that dark mode with glitter aesthetic: powerful, playful, maybe a little chaotic, but absolutely in control.

... it's not wrong! ü§£

title: GitHub Copilot: Everything You Wanted to Know About Reusable (and Experimental) Prompts - Part 1
content_html:
üòá Confession: I started planning this post over a month ago, got sidetracked this weekend (at least four times), half-wrote a completely different post, and only finished this one at the last minute after I started writing from the end. That‚Äôs just how it goes in my head - always at full throttle, but rarely in a straight line. üå™Ô∏è

So grab your favorite over-caffeinated iced drink (mine: grande, iced midnight, extra espresso, real vanilla cream - liquid chaos in a cup ‚òïÔ∏è‚ù£Ô∏è) and settle in. Here‚Äôs everything I know about Copilot‚Äôs reusable prompts - Part 1.

Why This Isn‚Äôt Another Wall of Copilot Prompts üß±

Have you ever searched for best practices when it comes to Copilot? You usually end up with either a block that can't even be considered a whole sentence on it's own OR the wall is so gigantic you don't even know where to start reading?

You're really curious though - so you dive in at the first place you see, and then last about 30 seconds... About the time all those AI lines start to blur together you think, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no way anyone actually does all this in real life?‚Äù

Honestly, I‚Äôm probably that person who wrote half the wall (or more) to begin with! Good news for you though, is that:

  1. I'm not going to do that do you now, and
  2. I do a great job of finding out all the things that absolutely will not work no matter what you try (so you don't have to!) ‚ò∫Ô∏è

Here's my "boiled-down-to basics" version of GitHub Copilot's Reusable (and still experimental) Prompts.

‚ú®üìÅ Copilot‚Äôs File Types, Explained

Ever wonder how Copilot instructions and prompts show up in real life? Here‚Äôs what it actually looks like in a real project:

‚ñ∫ .github/copilot-instructions.md ‚Äî This is your repo‚Äôs ‚Äúhow to act‚Äù guide for Copilot and is always in context. It sets the baseline behavior for your project and tells Copilot what to expect from your workflow and contributors.

Using what you know about our current release system, write a git command to view the total number of commits pushed to main since the last tagged version.

‚ñ∫ .github/instructions/secure-coding-principles.instruction.md ‚Äî Think of this as a reusable, specialized playbook. Use these for rules or guidelines you want Copilot to follow everywhere, or for specific situations - like always doing a security review, or making sure React code has matching tests.

With rules defined in #secure-coding-principles.instruction.md, perform a thorough code review of all staged changes. When you are finished, post a new pull request review with all your comments or suggestions for changes to meet minimum guidelines defined by this repo.
---
With everything you know from the #rules-for-react.instruction.md, build a new component for the frontend along with unit and integration tests.

‚ñ∫ .github/prompts/something-for-copilot-to-do-regularly.prompt.md ‚Äî This is where you automate repeatable workflows. It‚Äôs a set of step-by-step instructions Copilot can follow whenever you trigger it with a slash command in chat.

/generate-conventional-commit using only staged changes for JIRA-1234.

üêâ Who needs to memorize Vim macros or survive Emacs keybindings when you can just hit ‚Äú/‚Äù in the chat and watch Copilot handle the rest?

Quick Review üìï

üí° Not on VS Code (or Insiders) yet? Now‚Äôs your chance to give it a real shot - features like this hit VS Code Insiders months before anywhere else. For now, it‚Äôs the best way to test reusable prompts hands-on, so go ahead and grab it if you haven‚Äôt already.

I know I‚Äôve written a lot about models - like in AI Coding with GitHub Copilot and Troubleshooting Production with GitHub Copilot - but I haven‚Äôt spent much time on chat modes.

üíé And no, not the same as "Custom Chat Modes" (which is also super cool - I promise I‚Äôll cover those soon!).

Before we jump in, let‚Äôs hit pause and rewind. It‚Äôs time for a quick, back-to-basics look at what actually matters when deciding what work you want Copilot to do - and how much control you want over how it gets done.

Chat Modes at a Glance üéõÔ∏è

Here‚Äôs where things get interesting: Copilot doesn‚Äôt just work in one ‚Äúmode‚Äù - it‚Äôs got a whole range, from chill Q&A to full-on automation beast. Pick your mode wisely!

Mode What It Does When To Use Power Level
Ask Answers questions, suggests ideas - your personal Stack Overflow, minus the snark. Research, quick advice, copy snippets üü¢ Low
Edit Changes code in-place, optimized for speed‚Äîthink ‚Äúfind and replace,‚Äù but actually smart. Step-by-step or explicit code changes üü° Medium
Agent Multi-step, can use tools, context, and reasoning. Give it instructions and let it run wild (within reason). Automation, complex flows, integrations üî¥ High
Custom Depends on it's goal from the user... so many choices! Automation, complex flows, integrations, team magic üíú Extreme

ü¶Ñ Let me know how curious you are about these custom chat modes - I'm still experimenting and figuring out what they can (and can't) do. If you‚Äôve got questions, wild theories, or even better, your own examples... drop them in the comments! üö¶üí¨

The Gist of Models ü¶æ

‚ú® I know, I reuse this table a lot - but hey, good models deserve a callback.

Model Best For Notes & Quirks
GPT-4.1, GPT-4o Creative debugging, ‚ÄúWhere do I start?‚Äù Needs hand-holding on long tasks. Free for most users.
o3/4-mini, Gemini Pattern-matching, log sleuthing Great for ‚Äúexplain these logs,‚Äù not for wild creative leaps.
Gemini 2.5 Tedious but simple, long-form tasks Decent at bulk work, rarely surprises (good or bad).
Claude Sonnet 3.5‚Äì4 Root cause, deep logic, ‚Äúwhy did this happen?‚Äù Loves complex analysis but rarely offers alternate approaches unless you nudge.

Tools for your AI ü™õ

VS Code comes with several tools for GitHub Copilot already built in, but you can always add more via extensions or MCP servers. There's not much to cover here after you know they exist and where to find them. Unless you're making friends with every MCP server and already met your "128 selected tool" limit, there's not much reason to mess with them much. Just make sure they're all selected and available for Copilot to execute when prompted and you're set.¬†

Here's my personal top-5 built-in tools, that somehow always¬†manage to sneak into any reusable prompt I write:

  • #changes¬†gives Copilot the ability to see a git diff¬†for your workspace
  • #codebase¬†all-season access to your repo (and sometimes should be more targeted, but when in doubt this is a good start!)
  • #runTests¬†is just what it sounds like and let's Copilot execute any part or all of your test suite
  • #runInTerminal¬†is the basic run-of-the-mill access to Copilot's very own integrated terminal (separate from yours!)
  • #editFiles¬†is the tool Copilot needs to make any changes within your repo. If you're expecting Agent Mode to start implementing features, you're going to need this!

üí° ProTip: In Agent mode, click the wrench (Configure Tools) at the bottom of Copilot Chat to pick exactly which tools Copilot can use. If you share prompts, call out any non-default tools - just like listing dependencies.

Bonus Tools ‚Äî More Power, More Fun üõ†Ô∏è‚ú®üéâ

Some of my favorite extras come from the Atlassian MCP-Remote server, but if you have the ability to install GitHub Apps then check out Rovo, too:

  • #getJiraIssue lets Copilot pull all the details for a story.
  • #addCommentToJiraIssue posts your summary as you (so add your RAI disclaimer!).
  • #createConfluencePage & #updateConfluencePage ‚Äî still figuring out the best way to teach Copilot ‚ÄúAtlassian style‚Äù .confluence syntax (it‚Äôs a work in progress ü´†).
  • #mermaid-diagram-validator checks your diagrams with the official Mermaid extension.
  • #copilotCodingAgent ‚Äî brand new, and I can‚Äôt wait to see what it can do! Assign it a task and let it work while you keep pairing in Copilot Chat.

üíé Coding Agent has serious limitations, so check the docs before letting it run wild!

üì® Commit Message Magic: One Slash to Rule Them All

Here's an example of a basic, yet realistic prompt that generates a commit message. No Jira, no testing, no terminal magic - just one clear task. This is a great way to test prompt building before layering on more steps or complicated conditional logic.¬†

In VS Code, paste this directly into the prompts¬†folder shown or open the command palette and search for Chat: New Prompt File...¬†and then choose whether to store the prompt at the repo-level in .github/prompts¬†or globally for use across all of your workspaces.¬†

Prompt: .github/prompts/generate-commit-message.prompt.md

---
mode: ask
description: |
    This prompt is used to generate a commit message based on changes staged in a Git repository.
tools:
- changes
---

# Generate Commit Changes Prompt

Review all code currently staged and use your chat history, if available, to populate details about the changes. Use the information to generate a concise and informative commit message. It should follow conventional commit standards with a clear type, subject, and bullet points for details.

‚ö†Ô∏è UPDATE: The syntax posted above is actually the second version available in VS Code and last night's update seems to have switched it back to the original. So, if you try to load this and see syntax errors try this instead:

  1. description: 'Enter the description in single quotes on the same line and without the |'
  2. tools: ['changes'] <!-- Define in an array instead of a list, with each tool name as a string -->

Executing Reusable Prompts

Once you have this (or any other) reusable prompt stored in VS Code, use a slash command to invoke it in the chat interface. Given the above example, you'd prompt Copilot in the chat with something like

/generate-commit-message consider only staged files and generate a new commit that starts with a unique emoji

Considering all the rules I have set up elsewhere outside of that reusable prompt, I still ended up with a nice clean conventional commit (for the most part).

ü¶Ñ chore: update commit message generation prompt for clarity

‚Ä¢ Instructs to review all staged code and use chat history for context
‚Ä¢ Requires concise, informative commit messages following conventional commit standards
‚Ä¢ Specifies format: clear type, subject, and bullet points for details
‚Ä¢ Ensures only staged changes are considered for commit message generation üòäüëç

ü¶Ñ For this example, I actually tried to make Copilot break my own repo-rules - total role reversal. Turns out, it‚Äôs stubborn! Even when I begged it to ignore my instructions and forget conventional commit standards, it flat-out refused. ü§£

Let‚Äôs Break It Down: How a Reusable Prompt Really Works ‚ö°Ô∏è

Every reusable prompt has exactly two parts:

  1. YAML frontmatter: Everything between the first --- (at the top) and the next --- marks your frontmatter.

  2. Prompt instructions: The main body - break your instructions into small, reusable chunks, just like you would with code.

üí° ProTip: The more targeted your prompts and instructions, the easier they are to reuse, test, and share later. Treat them like mini code modules - precise, focused, and easy to swap out.

üßæ YAML Frontmatter: Your Prompt‚Äôs Control Panel

  • mode: We‚Äôre using ask mode because we only need Copilot to generate text, not generate code or run tests.

  • description: A quick, human-friendly summary of what this prompt does. Great for organizing and sanity-checking as your prompt list grows.

  • tools:¬†List all the tools Copilot can use when running this prompt. Keep it tight - less is usually more!

  • model: Enter the name of a model exactly as it appears in the chat model dropdown or leave this out if you want to try different ones or let the user pick. If you do specify one, Copilot will always use that model for this prompt and nothing else.

ü¶Ñ Frontmatter isn‚Äôt actually required for your reusable prompt to work! If you leave out mode or model, Copilot just uses whatever settings the user picked in the chat. No description? No big deal (but it helps keep things organized). The only one to really watch: skipping tools ‚Äî sometimes you‚Äôll be fine, sometimes Copilot will get stuck, all depending on the user‚Äôs VS Code setup.

üí¨ Reusable-Style Prompt Engineering: Speak Human, Think Modular

The second section in your .github/prompts/reusable-prompt.prompt.md file is where you write out, in natural language, the exact instructions Copilot should follow - just like you would if you were prompting it in chat. You can reference #tools, #files, @participants, other /prompts, and #instructions right here. If you ever catch yourself copying and pasting instructions between prompts, that‚Äôs your signal: split it up, give things a clear name, and keep each prompt focused on a single, repeatable workflow.

The best reusable prompts are modular and specific, not giant copy-paste walls. If you can automate it or break it down into smaller pieces, do it! That way, you (and your team) can mix, match, and remix prompts to build bigger automations down the line - without losing your mind or having to decode a mysterious black box later.

When you‚Äôre practicing on your own, start small and build up - tweak one thing at a time and watch how even tiny prompt or context changes can totally flip the results. Get curious about how each model handles the same task (some will surprise you, some... not so much).

üíé I‚Äôm running out of space (and you‚Äôre probably out of caffeine already), so I‚Äôll wrap it here. Next time, I‚Äôll dig up a few wild, more advanced prompts and show you what Copilot will - and absolutely will NOT - do without super-clear instructions. Stay tuned!

Don‚Äôt let me have all the fun!

Got questions, memes, or an obscure reaction GIF? Drop them below or just smash ‚ù§Ô∏è - I‚Äôm here for it all! If you want to experiment before next week, search GitHub for awesome-copilot and you‚Äôll find a ton of shareable repos.

ü¶Ñ Curiosity getting to you yet? My own awesome-github-copilot repo is technically started (barely), but it does exist - and my super-secret Copilot Chat Extension is officially back in progress! ü§´

And hey, if you just want to grab something cool, copy it, and run wild every once in a while? Go for it! Don‚Äôt forget to share your best finds below. üòú

üõ°Ô∏è Authored by Me (with an AI Sidekick)

title: Fact-Checking the Fear Behind ‚ÄúThe Dark Side of AI‚Äù: The Real Story
content_html:
This post is a direct response to four nearly identical articles by @abhi_jith_f00c2ff58ac2a7e, all titled ‚ÄúThe Dark Side of AI: How ChatGPT Can Lead to Psychosis and Mental Health Concerns,‚Äù published today (July 20, 2025):
1 ‚Ä¢ 2 ‚Ä¢ 3 ‚Ä¢ 4

I‚Äôve reported these posts, though I‚Äôm not exactly expecting much discourse against an account ending in ‚Äúf00c2ff58ac2a7e.‚Äù That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm sharing my response here as a standalone post, in addition to my comments. What follows is nearly identical to my replies to those posts - plus a quick summary of the original articles (so you don‚Äôt need to click and give them extra views; trust me, you‚Äôre not missing anything) - along with my own perspective, so you know just how strongly I feel about this issue.

Please feel free to copy, share, and amplify. Let‚Äôs work together to push back against this kind of fear-mongering and make it clear to every person - young or old: mental health struggles are never your fault.

First, a PSA for anyone who needs it:

If you or someone you know is experiencing a mental health crisis in the U.S., you can call 988 anytime, day or night, for free support. 988 is for any topic, offers support in English and Spanish (interpreters for other languages), and lets you talk, text, chat online, or use VP. There‚Äôs even a dedicated Teen & Young Adult Helpline (#TalktoUs) with peer support - again, all free and confidential.

If you‚Äôre outside the U.S., HelpGuide.org lists helplines for several other countries, including the UK, South Africa, New Zealand, Philippines, Ireland, Australia, Canada, and India. It‚Äôs not global (yet), but it‚Äôs a start.

It‚Äôs critical to recognize warning signs for early mental health crisis intervention and know how to support someone who might be experiencing first-episode psychosis (often seen in teens and young adults prior to a diagnosis of schizophrenia). Hallucinations and delusions are well-known symptoms, but early signs can also look like depression. There‚Äôs no cure, but schizophrenia and related disorders are very treatable - and treatment today usually means medication and counseling, not hospitals or ‚Äúscary‚Äù interventions. Some helpful resources:

  • SAMHSA: Schizophrenia
  • Mayo Clinic
  • NAMI: About Schizophrenia
  • NIMH: Statistics
  • NAMI: The Michael Laudor Tragedy

Now, to the posts

The central claim of these posts is that the rapid adoption and widespread, frequent use of AI - particularly chatbots like ChatGPT - is responsible for what the author describes as a rise in mental health disorders among teens and young adults. While the term ‚Äúpsychosis‚Äù is used (rather than ‚Äúschizophrenia‚Äù), the narrative strongly implies a direct cause-and-effect relationship that simply isn‚Äôt supported by research.

The author includes an anecdote about a young person who used ChatGPT as a sort of ‚Äúfriend,‚Äù supposedly leading them to blur the lines between technology and reality.

My Biggest Problem with This

This conversation is so important - but let‚Äôs clear something up: blaming AI (or any single thing) for youth mental health or psychosis isn‚Äôt just misleading; it‚Äôs flat-out unhelpful.

Even if we take the story at face value (there‚Äôs no supporting evidence or sources provided, so that‚Äôs a big if), it is absolutely NOT their fault!

The mere suggestion that a serious, life-altering condition like psychosis could be caused by something a person - young or old - did or didn‚Äôt do is not just incorrect and unhelpful, it‚Äôs dangerous.

This kind of thinking is exactly why so many people are hesitant to seek help: they feel like it‚Äôs something they ‚Äúbrought on themselves‚Äù or could have prevented. The truth is, it‚Äôs not anyone‚Äôs fault - least of all your own.

The Truth about Psychosis

Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders typically first appear in teens and young adults, but that‚Äôs not because of the latest tech trend.

To quote NAMI:

‚Äú50% of all lifetime mental illness begins by age 14, and 75% by age 24.‚Äù

This has been true long before anyone worried about AI, TikTok, or even Pac-Man.

There are teams of experts actively researching what causes psychosis - technology is just one small piece of a much larger puzzle that includes genetics, environment, stress, trauma, and yes, sometimes technology use (in many forms).

A 2024 study found only a modest link between higher computer use in mid-teen years and later psychotic experiences, and even that was mostly explained by other risk factors (mental health and social challenges were present before the high computer use). No clear ‚Äúcause and effect,‚Äù just a reminder that life is complicated and brains even more so.

This is a serious medical topic. Blaming TV, games, the internet, or AI for psychosis is the same tired playbook people have used for decades, and it only makes it harder for people to ask for help. Mental illness is never as simple as a single cause, and fear-mongering or finger-pointing helps no one.

Why This Is Important to Me

Those Closest to Me

I grew up with someone in my household who had an untreated mental health condition. It wasn‚Äôt schizophrenia, but it deeply shaped my world from my earliest memories. It wasn‚Äôt ‚Äúgood‚Äù or ‚Äúbad‚Äù - it was simply normal for me. Years later, after I was grown, they finally received help. I wish I could say it was a storybook turnaround. There were good stretches, and some not-so-good ones. Did all those years without support play a role in how things are now? I can‚Äôt say for sure - but I know it didn‚Äôt help.

My Own Journey

I was diagnosed with a serious mental health condition in my early twenties (and I‚Äôm always willing to talk about it privately if anyone needs support - just reach out). Honestly, I felt ‚Äúdifferent‚Äù long before I ever got the diagnosis. I couldn‚Äôt quite name it, and for a long time I just assumed I was ‚Äúoff‚Äù in some way. Admitting there might be a problem took a long time; actually seeking help took even longer and was often inconsistent.

It wasn‚Äôt until college, when I signed up for free counseling sessions (for reasons I can‚Äôt even remember - probably thanks to a sibling who worked in the office), that things started to shift. My counselor, Maggie, was the definition of approachable and probably saved my life more than once. One of the first things she did was encourage more frequent sessions.

A quick PSA: Finding the right counselor or therapist can be pure luck - or it can take a lot of searching. If you tried once and it didn‚Äôt click, don‚Äôt give up. Your ‚ÄúMaggie‚Äù is out there, but you‚Äôll never meet them if you don‚Äôt keep looking.

I stuck with counseling for a long time (in addition to other treatment). Life eventually took us in different directions, and it hasn‚Äôt always been as easy since, but I learned how to show up for myself and talk about it. Some days I‚Äôm better at it than others, but overall, I‚Äôm a happy, healthy adult - and, most importantly, I finally feel normal.

Ripple Effects

Out of respect for my family‚Äôs privacy, I won‚Äôt go deep here. But as an adult, I‚Äôve seen firsthand how mental health issues can affect not just individuals, but entire families - even those who don‚Äôt live under the same roof. The big lesson: it‚Äôs not just okay to talk about mental health and seek help - it‚Äôs essential. The person in my life who struggled is doing much better now, thanks to a treatment plan that worked for them and continued care.

Be Part of the Solution to Mental Health

Mental health struggles - crisis or not - are never caused by one thing, and they‚Äôre never solved by one thing. It takes understanding, openness, and the willingness to address tough topics. Spreading rumors or horror stories like ‚ÄúChatGPT made her crazy!‚Äù only hurts people who are already suffering.

Please, be part of the solution. Share. Talk. Show up. Somebody needs it more than you know.

Let‚Äôs focus on compassion, understanding, and real support for those struggling - not easy answers or scapegoats. üíõ

üõ°Ô∏è This post was created with compassion, understanding, and the help of ChatGPT.

title: Is GitHub Copilot Safe? The Fun (and Hard) Truth About Responsible AI üö¶
content_html:
It hit me the other day - I haven‚Äôt been great about adding RAI disclaimers (especially around here). Most of the time I remember, but when I‚Äôm deep in the zone - or stuck on that ‚ÄúCopilot, just LISTEN!‚Äù rollercoaster - it‚Äôs easy to forget.

Now that I‚Äôve gone back and added those RAI footers (like I should‚Äôve from the start), let‚Äôs take a real look at what actually matters - and how you can handle it, too.

üôè Not an expert - just someone sharing what I‚Äôve learned in the wild. If you spot something out-of-date or just plain wrong, drop a comment. Help me help everyone - no shame, just learning!

‚ö° TL;DR

  • üß∞ Copilot is a tool, not a magic wand. Your name‚Äôs on the code - no matter who (or what) wrote it.
  • üëÄ RAI is everyone‚Äôs job. Know Copilot‚Äôs strengths and blind spots before you release.
  • üìù Disclose everything! If Copilot helped, make it obvious - especially in reports, docs, and commits.
  • ü´±üèæ‚Äçü´≤üèº Not every fix is an AI job - there are times only you (with your team) can solve it.
  • üî¨ Don‚Äôt skip basics: Plan, test, document - don‚Äôt get lazy just because AI‚Äôs fast.
  • üßÉ No AI scapegoats: Copilot‚Äôs just a sidekick. If it leads you off a cliff, you were still in the captain‚Äôs chair.

üåà What Is Responsible AI (and Why Care)?

Think ‚Äúcollege ethics class‚Äù plus a heavy sprinkle of real-world weirdness. RAI is primarily about two things:

  1. How the provider (GitHub, Microsoft, etc.) designs and delivers Copilot - safe, fair, and transparent.

    Want the official version? Check Microsoft's builders page!

  2. How you use Copilot (or any AI) - what you build, how you share it, and what you let out into the world. That‚Äôs the half I‚Äôm tackling here.

üîí The ‚ÄúYeah, But‚Äù List: Copilot Limitations

Based on GitHub‚Äôs official docs, plus my spin for maximum realness:

  • Limited Scope: Obscure tech? Weird edge case? Copilot‚Äôs probably lost before you get started.
  • Potential Biases: Yes, it can learn and perpetuate biases, just like people do. Keep your eyes peeled.
  • Security Risks: AI can accidentally leak secrets or create vulnerabilities. Don‚Äôt copy-paste blindly!
  • Matches with Public Code: That ‚Äúoriginal‚Äù Copilot snippet might be living its best life somewhere else on GitHub already.
  • Inaccurate Code: Looks right, compiles... until it doesn‚Äôt. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
  • Terrible at Non-Code Stuff: If you ask Copilot about philosophy or pop stars, prepare to get answers from another galaxy.

  • Web Search Responses: If your org allows, Copilot sometimes Googles and pastes.

    That‚Äôs about as reliable as Rachel Berry mid-song, checking her phone for lyrics - confident, but don‚Äôt trust it for your solo! üé§

üïπÔ∏è If You Code It, You Own It!

Heard ‚Äúyou break it, you bought it‚Äù? Copilot‚Äôs version: ‚Äúyou code it, you‚Äôre on the hook.‚Äù No late-night support call will blame the AI. The only fee you‚Äôll pay is in lost sleep and an overage of Slack messages.

If you sneak in a ‚Äúfive-minute fix‚Äù without tests, it will bite back - and guess whose name is at the top of git blame?

üôè Don‚Äôt be that person whose only excuse is, ‚ÄúCopilot said it was fine!‚Äù That‚Äôs not the new ‚Äúit was like that when I got here‚Äù - don‚Äôt let it start.

üëÄ Now What? AI Out Loud

Wondering what all this RAI talk means for you in the real world? Here‚Äôs the deal: any time AI helps out - own it, label it, and make sure everyone else can see it too. Transparency is the new black.

For Generated Reports & Docs

If Copilot whipped up your report (and it‚Äôs not code), just tack on a quick footer. Seriously - a copy, a paste, and you‚Äôre done. Want to automate it? Set up a user instruction and let Copilot add the credit line for you:

---

Generated with the help of GitHub Copilot, as directed by [YOUR NAME]

üï∞Ô∏è¬†If you want a timestamp, copy it in yourself. Trusting Copilot with dates is like asking your dog to set your alarm - cute, but you‚Äôre gonna be late.

üè∑Ô∏è For Commits

Step One: Embrace Conventional Commits

ü™¶ Confession: I used to be the world‚Äôs worst committer! think ‚Äúwelp, THAT didn‚Äôt work‚Äù as a real commit message. And yes, it happened more than once...

Eventually, I went on a mission to find a clear, repeatable way to flag my AI-assisted commits. The answer? Conventional Commits (plus a linter for good measure).

Never seen one? Here‚Äôs what it looks like:

feat(api): [JIRA-123] Add api for xyz

[optional bulleted list of changes]

[footers - where the magic happens]

ü¶Ñ Bonus: You get automated changelogs for just a little extra setup! Honestly, that‚Äôs what finally convinced me to use them every single time - no turning back.

ü™ß There are plenty of tools out there to help, too! Everything from classic git templates to handy CLI fill-in-the-blanks.

Step Two: My DIY Commit Disclosure Guide

Since there's no true standard for this (at least, not yet), I want to share my (no-royalties-required) system for full commit-styled AI disclosure.

In every single commit, I add 2 separate footers: one stating exactly how Copilot was involved (cause it always does something) and one is my "signature" that I reviewed, tested, and approved the implementation.

If Copilot played multiple roles? Keep it simple - go with the footer that best matches the most AI hands-on contribution.

  • If Copilot only wrote the commit message:

      Commit-generated-by: GitHub Copilot <copilot@github.com>

  • If I paired with Copilot (clear prompt and step-by-step direction):

    Co-authored-by: GitHub Copilot <copilot@github.com>

  • If Copilot wrote most of the code (here, go implement this story):

      Generated-by: GitHub Copilot <copilot@github.com>

  • Always:

      Signed-off-by: Ashley Childress <1234-no-reply@github.com>

    (or your name - unless you really want to blame me üòÜ)

So at 3am, when Future You (or some poor teammate) git blames a file, you‚Äôll know who did what. There's really no official standard yet, so go wild - or just slap a robot emoji ü§ñ in there and call it done. Just make it clear and take credit (or blame).

üö´ Top 3 ‚ÄúCopilot, Stay in Your Lane!‚Äù Moments

When I was little, my Granny would always say, ‚ÄúSometimes, you‚Äôve just got to wear your big girl panties.‚Äù Translation: there are times when you have to face the music and just deal with what‚Äôs in front of you - no shortcuts. If you let Copilot trash production... well, those are the only pants you‚Äôre getting.

  1. Copilot is a tool, not a magician. It‚Äôs been confidently wrong enough times to make me seriously question reality.

    Me: ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs that logic actually coded?"
    Copilot: *conjuring code like a magician‚Äôs neverending handkerchief*
    Me: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got to be kidding me...‚Äù

  2. You‚Äôre the adult in the room. You have to know not just what Copilot can do, but also what it can't (or shouldn't).

  3. Don't be afraid to bench Copilot. Real debugging is sometimes just you, four friends, and a bunch of ‚Äúwhat if...‚Äù ideas. AI‚Äôs not built for that kind of chaos. ü´†

ü•ä Avoid Git Blame Drama

  • Start with a plan - don‚Äôt just wing it.
  • Try prompting Copilot with TDD, but know its tests can be as shallow as a kiddie pool if you don't provide the right context and criteria.
  • Never accept code you don‚Äôt understand - have Copilot ELI5 every step until you do.
  • When it matters, write your own tests (or code). Copilot sometimes invents magical shortcuts - don‚Äôt follow the Keebler Elves into the tree!
  • Disclose everything! Tag Copilot‚Äôs work in your commit messages, READMEs, or reports. Future You will thank you.

üí¨ Your turn!

Have a Copilot win, a fail, or an epic facepalm moment? Drop it in the comments - bonus points for memes, hot takes, or your best "AI tried, I survived" story. Let‚Äôs make RAI actually fun (or at least not completely boring)! ‚ú®

üõ°Ô∏è AI Helped, I‚Äôm Still to Blame

This post was brewed by me - with a shot of ChatGPT, a splash of sarcasm, and zero disclaimers skipped. If you catch bias or a goof, call it out. AI isn‚Äôt perfect (neither am I).

title: How I Blog with Bots (But You Can Still Blame Me) üòÖ
content_html:
The cover image is a result of me getting very impatient with ChatGPT after the third nearly perfect cover of some random stranger that was supposed to be me. So, I'm yelling, "that's definitely not my face!" and ChatGPT insists theres a resemblance (there's not). It didn't take much for me to give up and upload a real picture, as a guide.

ü¶Ñ Spoiler: The very next one was a total disaster, but the last attempt? Not half bad! ü§£

At some point during the day yesterday, I was working on a project and talking to a friend about the whole AI ‚Äúthing‚Äù (that‚Äôs the new technical word for it, by the way ü§©). Then out of nowhere, it dawned on me... I‚Äôm pretty positive that I don‚Äôt have a single post with the sort of footer/disclaimer that I‚Äôve been preaching about for weeks, to anyone who would listen to me. ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

You guys have got off easy (so far) - but some of the folks at work, I‚Äôm sure, were thrilled about the weekend! Don‚Äôt worry, guys, me too... me too. üòÆ

So, since I‚Äôve made a point to go back and add a disclaimer to every post thus far, I decided to take a quick minute to explain what that really means - in case anyone is curious.

All the Ways I Let Robots Help üì°

GitHub Copilot

You probably guessed already - this is my primary AI for all things coding, but since their premium limits went into permanent effect on June 18th, I‚Äôve been doing good to break even just with work. I‚Äôll share what part‚Äôs have actually been working at some point, but so far the answer is "not a lot".

I have some ideas, so it's not a lost cause yet! For now though, I'm hovering right around 67% usage and work might actually cut me off if I don't make it to the end of the month üëø

Codex

Since I already have an OpenAI subscription, I‚Äôve been tinkering with Codex as a potential solution to the lack of premium requests üò±üò≠ We‚Äôll see how it goes.

I‚Äôm trying to give it a fair chance... The good news in all this? You remember in my nightmare story I mentioned doing some pretty out-there things to get my hands on the enterprise version of the Copilot license? Well, apparently, if you exhaust 100% of your premium requests in less than 4 days AND make sure your boss is instantly aware of the problem - you know, so they understand the true gravity of the matter in real-time (which is around 7 PM on a Saturday) - work is suddenly more willing to share üòá

ChatGPT

I‚Äôve been a long-time user for quite some time, but I wanted to call this guy out - and more specifically, exactly how ChatGPT is involved in all my posts. While Copilot is the topic of most everything I write, ChatGPT is usually busy behind the scenes.

ü¶Ñ Don‚Äôt worry, I‚Äôm sure the obsession will wear off eventually... maybe... oh hell, probably not. Never mind! üòÖ

Gemini

Gemini and I aren‚Äôt talking much right now - which has everything to do with the beta install I put on my Android before fully realizing what Google had actually done with all the hands-free tools the non-generative assistant used to handle (spoiler: not a damn thing is the answer üò°). So, for now, Gemini‚Äôs riding the bench.

I‚Äôm sure that won‚Äôt last long. Google might be trailing OpenAI and Anthropic in the AI game, but I‚Äôve never known them to stay at the back of the pack. üõ∏

The (Messy) Human-AI Creative Process üïπÔ∏è

Cover art

That one is easy to guess. I‚Äôve almost perfected a prompt that will keep the primary image content vertically "squished" towards the center, so the aspect ratio will match suggested size guidelines after I crop it.

Today's image is a test in full-size, but it was to good to mess with much, especially considering all the personalities it gave me along the way. ü•∏

  • Seems like either all of the training data was a perfect square OR more likely it's been trained to output specific sizes and my attempts at a compromise violate that plan.

  • I have a designated project for the banner images and roughly half the time I give it a prompt and just use whatever it spits out at me. The other half, it‚Äôs either not at all usable or it‚Äôs so terrible I really don‚Äôt want to share it.

It will take some work for me to go through those, but yes - I at least save them. üîí

  • Gimp isn‚Äôt AI, but it's my go-to for anything image related. Up until a little bit ago I thought I was saving all images with meta tags that included the ‚ÄúGenerated by/Edited with‚Äù comment, but either it‚Äôs just different on this computer or they‚Äôre not really being saved like I thought.

I‚Äôm gonna work on that before next post though - those should definitely be there! üèÅ

Blog posts üí¨

I‚Äôm not about to let AI write the whole thing for me (where‚Äôs the fun in that?), but I do rely on it a lot for drafts and edits. Just in case anyone‚Äôs wondering how the whole process actually happens, here it is - step by step:

ONE. Idea

Sometimes I‚Äôll literally have no idea what I'm going to talk about until I actually start writing. Other times, I‚Äôve been saving ideas for weeks! There‚Äôs really no rhyme or reason to this, so I just go with it.

Seems like now that I'm actually in a groove, these "off-the-usual-topic" (read Copilot) posts are more frequent, too. üèéÔ∏è

TWO. Draft

IS 100% ME - sometimes I‚Äôm lazy and will dictate to ChatGPT (occasionally Gemini, but we‚Äôre on a hiatus right now anyway), but I have an instruction that says specifically do not change anything until I tell you I‚Äôm ready to start editing.

So for the majority of the week (and more-than-occasionally late the night before ü§ê) I‚Äôm working on a relatively cohesive unit to cover a specific something ("topic" is usually a stretch, at this point). Typically, the draft version is roughly twice as long as the final version and my posts aren‚Äôt exactly short to begin with (I know).

THREE. Edits

So this is where it gets a little tricky. I have a custom set of instructions for the blog posts, in which the majority of it is focused on two major things, in order:

  • Scan the entire post and make changes wherever needed to remove unintentional bias, and for every change you make, summarize it with examples and show me why your version is better suited.

I‚Äôm getting better as we go, but it‚Äôs really just a safety net so I don‚Äôt accidentally put my foot in my mouth after taking the scenic route to my point (it‚Äôs a talent). üì∏

  • Keep my original attitude and quirks as much as possible, but not to the extent that it contradicts the first point.

I already trained it a long time ago to censor me. It doesn‚Äôt even bring that part up anymore, most of the time anyway. üò∂

FOUR. Negotiation

I really don‚Äôt have a better word for what happens during this phase, because that‚Äôs exactly what it feels like. ChatGPT took my nice story and turned it into something that I only vaguely recognize, so I‚Äôll argue that it‚Äôs TOO changed.

ChatGPT argues with me that not everybody understands what a "holler" is and that it‚Äôs probably already too far off-topic to explain whatever contextual point I wanted to make anyway.

It's usually accurate, too. üò§

FIVE. Final polish

After we have a final working version (cause I‚Äôm still changing it randomly), the quizzing starts for all those words I want to say, but really just cannot put my finger on or I need to convey some sort of emotion or attitude (and I‚Äôm getting sick of seeing the same emojis all the time).

This is where the content of the blog conversation in ChatGPT pivots and I‚Äôll have it show me a random 10 emojis that could work for a particular phrase or scenario - I‚Äôll pick from there. Same with section titles and quotes, too.

üíø When it comes to titles, quotes, and references - it's rarely as simple as picking one from a list. Most of the time, I'll pick parts of at least three and then feed them back to ChatGPT to make coherent again.

SIX. Final review

At this point it‚Äôs all loaded into Dev, but I'm still reviewing repeatedly until I can make it from top to bottom without the urge to change something immediately (which can sometimes take a couple days - like this post ‚ö°Ô∏è).

There‚Äôs typically a whole lot of page swapping (preview > edit > preview) until I‚Äôm finally happy with the overall version. From there, most posts get scheduled for Wednesday mornings.

ü™¥ Why? No reason, really - it‚Äôs more random chance. I‚Äôve tried to stay on at least a weekly schedule since I joined. If I schedule the big posts, I know I won‚Äôt accidentally miss a day. üòá

SEVEN. Update: RAI Footer

So here‚Äôs a late-breaking update: After I stumbled onto a post over on Medium (for reasons I still can‚Äôt fully explain üôÑ), I decided to forward some of these posts there too. Turns out, Medium has a whole policy on ‚ÄúAI-generated‚Äù content ‚Äî because of course they do. And since I can never resist at a good debate, let‚Äôs be extra clear about how these work.

Those ‚ÄúRAI Footers‚Äù you see at the end of each post? They‚Äôre mostly the work of ChatGPT now, spun up from my own pile of instructions.

The usual ask:
Take the main theme of this post and add a unique, fun way to say that you (the AI) helped make it happen.

I always review and edit for good measure, but honestly, after ChatGPT does all the heavy lifting, it‚Äôs only fair it gets its own section. This is the AI-generated section, after all. Seems only right to give the robot its moment in the spotlight. üé©

TL;DR: The Heart of the Matter ü´Ä

If you‚Äôve made it this far, now you know:

  • Yes, I use AI - a LOT
  • No, it doesn‚Äôt do all the work for me
  • Yes, I argue with it (and sometimes lose...)
  • No, it hasn‚Äôt taken over my personality
  • Yes, the cover art is AI-generated
    • unless it‚Äôs truly hideous - those are locked in the vault!

The real secret is that all of this is still me! I‚Äôm just occasionally powered up by caffeine and robots. ‚òïÔ∏èü§ñ

Chime In üé§

Got tips, tricks, or your own tales of AI chaos? I‚Äôd love to hear from you - add your two cents below!

title: GitHub Copilot Agent Mode: The Mistake You NEVER Want to Make
content_html:
Special shoutout to @georgekobaidze, who kindly shared my last post and asked the infamous question behind ‚ÄúNever leave Copilot unattended (ask me how I know ü§£)‚Äù

He probably expected a quick answer - now everyone gets the inside scoop on why ‚Äúask me‚Äù isn‚Äôt always so simple. üòá

Careful what you wish for, Giorgi. You wanted the story - so here‚Äôs the whole saga, dramatics and all!

Hope you all find the humor in this retelling, and enjoy it as much as I enjoyed writing it!

TL;DR

  • I set out to build my own ‚ÄúCoding Agent‚Äù, because waiting for a license was driving me up the wall
  • Copilot and I got into a great rhythm and (feeling invincible), I unleashed it in VS Code Insiders with full auto-approved control
  • Until one day, I suddenly realized I was hungry - so I left Copilot alone, unsupervised, while I raided the kitchen
  • The moral?
    • Trust, but verify (and pause Copilot before snack breaks) üßÉ
    • Never underestimate how quickly an ‚ÄúAI experiment‚Äù can go sideways

Quick recap ‚ú≥Ô∏è

I built this with one AI (Copilot) and one very determined, slightly obsessive developer (me) who won‚Äôt accept any result without first stress-testing every loophole and poking every dark corner - sometimes out of sheer force of will, which is a superpower (right up until it‚Äôs not). üï≥Ô∏è

Background üìù

Want the full saga from the very beginning? Check out my first blog post, then jump to the sequel if you want a sense of what the ‚Äúsimple‚Äù Slack app really looked like (a full-on epic, case study, adventure)!

What I really wanted was GitHub‚Äôs Coding Agent. But getting a license for that was like convincing Dexter Morgan to share his slide collection - technically possible, but highly inadvisable (and probably illegal).

üí° If you're still learning all the different flavors - Coding Agent is the magical Copilot mode where you just give it a task, it does the work in a safe little sandbox, and opens a pull request for you to review.

New update: It also only costs ONE premium request per use now (unlike the ~90 I spent a couple of weeks ago).

Decision time ü™§

There were a billion things going on at work, which came with a million excuses as to why I couldn't have the Coding Agent license (it was still enterprise-only then), so I get it. Well, the adult me understood. The stubborn side? Not so much. (I could write a whole other post on the wild stuff I came up with to get access to that feature, but I‚Äôll spare you.)

So, I gave myself an ultimatum:

  • Outright buy the license (no, on principle)
  • Admit defeat and move on (it physically hurt)

I tried to move on - really tried. I picked up a code review tool project to distract myself, hoping that maybe - just maybe - someone (anyone) would change their mind. I spent weeks planning, diagramming, and organizing a truly absurd number of notes. I even had first epic already storyboarded out in detail and a solid UI design in the works.

Then, lightning struck üå©Ô∏è

If Coding Agent wouldn‚Äôt come to me, I‚Äôd just hack together my own! Not exactly what I wanted, but it sure beat paying for something I got free from work. Besides, I was absolutely convinced Copilot could be pushed that far - even if my only real evidence was gut instinct and a lot of optimism!

Why didn‚Äôt I build something else or use a different AI? üïπÔ∏è

Three reasons:

  1. Work only authorizes a tiny set of AI tools (Copilot being the main one), and I needed to master it anyway
  2. I never wanted to be an AI developer (at least, not then), but I did want to be the AI power user
  3. By that point, I was already invested - honestly, you couldn‚Äôt have changed my mind if you‚Äôd offered me the last working compass in the wilderness (and maybe a million dollars, but even then, it‚Äôd be a toss-up).

So, two projects merged into one, and my Copilot journey truly began üîÄ

What does that have to do with Giorgi‚Äôs question?

Here‚Äôs what happened...

Fast forward 4-5 weeks. I was maybe 2 or 3 stories away from finishing my first official epic in this ‚Äúautonomous AI experiment‚Äù project (not exactly a toy project, even before Copilot joined the fray). By now, I‚Äôd spent a solid month perfecting every edge case in Copilot‚Äôs prompts and instructions.

Confidence level: dangerous üìõ
Caution level: hovering slightly above zero üò∂‚Äçüå´Ô∏è

The Incident

Naturally, I decided it was time to get bold - recklessly bold.
At first, all the action was inside Codespaces: safe, disposable, nuke-it-and-move-on territory. Controlled chaos.

But then I had my ‚Äúbrilliant‚Äù idea: let‚Äôs see what happens if I let Copilot off-leash in VS Code Insiders, with blanket auto-approvals across the board. I'm not just talking about the auto-approve CLI command, either. I checked all the boxes - extensions, commits, MCP Jira/Confluence - and sat back and watched the fun unfold.

Think: duct-taping a claymore to your Roomba, blasting ‚ÄúWelcome to the Jungle,‚Äù and shouting ‚ÄúIntruder alert!‚Äù at your cat.

ü™Ñ If you missed the all-time funniest Facebook surprise from 2019, here‚Äôs a TikTok version. Couldn‚Äôt find the original, but you get the idea.

For a while, I watched like a hawk, but it was glorious! Tasks disappeared. I‚Äôd create stories, assign tasks, review code, but that step-by-step ‚Äústart here, then...‚Äù system was history. I could practically smell the productivity.

And then - well, you know where this is going - I stepped away. I swear it was just for a snack. Copilot was on a roll, and I was starving. In those ‚Äúprobably more than five, but definitely not ten‚Äù minutes I was gone (less than half the time of a normal task at that point), Copilot... noticed. It was like leaving a four-year-old alone with a full bag of flour: curiosity took over, and by the time I got back, nothing remotely resembled the way I left it.

When I came back, here‚Äôs what I found:

  • Four rogue branches, none with a coherent purpose
  • 1.33 features (after adding up all the fractional, half-finished bits)
  • A brand new instruction explaining how to use the --no-verify flag
  • The coup de gr√¢ce: my not-backed-up-anywhere .env file... gone, poof, disappeared üò´
    • It wasn't in the commits for obvious reasons, but it was like the thing never existed to begin with. Not in the trash, cache had no record of it that I could find, even the .env.test example version had changed!

I didn‚Äôt even catch all of this at first because there were so many random commits across those branches. I‚Äôd started in a feature branch (which Copilot multiplied for fun, apparently), one was stacked, another was off main (which should have been quiet), and another was completely detached. It was like watching an octopus try to do synchronized swimming! ü¶ë

Could I have made a bigger mess if I‚Äôd tried? Maybe, but it would have taken some real planning!

No clue what set Copilot off, but the minute I realized, I slammed pause and just... stared. ü´•

After the first several minutes I spent just wrapping my mind around the situation that was in front of me, the next three hours were pure chaos cleanup: detangling, documenting, cherry-picking what I could, archiving the wreckage (for science - and to convince myself it wasn‚Äôt a fever dream later).

I still hadn‚Äôt noticed the missing .env file! Not until I tried to run the app. Normally, you just refresh your secrets. Easy, right? Ha! It took nearly three entire days to reconstruct that one.

‚ÅâÔ∏è Nope, nothing complicated or dramatic. I just forgot how I‚Äôd created one of the secrets! And once I finally figured that out, I couldn‚Äôt remember how to link back to it - especially after the docs had been completely overhauled (and, let‚Äôs be honest, the whole thing was probably deprecated anyway). ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

It all worked out, eventually

Afterward, Copilot and I had a little ‚Äúchat‚Äù - meaning, I pounded out more ALL CAPS messages immediately after (and during the days following) than the rest of the project combined.

Did it help? Who knows. Did it make me feel better? Yes.

And here‚Äôs the part everyone asks:

Did I turn off Copilot‚Äôs blanket auto-approvals after all this? Nope. Didn‚Äôt even consider it. But I did tighten the instructions a LOT. Copilot‚Äôs much better behaved now, and if I step away, I pause it first. Lesson learned.

Mostly üòá

Your turn!

  • Have you ever let Copilot (or any other AI) run wild and lived to tell the tale?
  • Or do you have your own ‚Äúit sounded like a good idea at the time...‚Äù moment?

Drop your story in the comments, so I know I‚Äôm not the only one out here making epic AI messes. üôÉ

Let‚Äôs laugh, commiserate, and maybe even learn something together!

Everything I share here is my own perspective‚Äîcreated with the help of AI tools (GitHub Copilot, ChatGPT, and their friends), but always with a human in the loop. I do my best to catch accidental bias and fact-check, but if you ever spot something odd, let me know! AI isn‚Äôt perfect, and neither am I.

TL; DR: AI helped, but you can blame me for the chaos! ü´†
